title.narrative: Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience

description.narrative: Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience of Rural Communities in Nusa Tenggara Timur Province (SPARC)

title.narrative: Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience
Strategic Planning and Action to Climate Resilience

description.narrative: SPARC project with support from GEF/Special Climate Change Fund (GEF/SCCF) funding will focus on strengthening and developing climate resilient institutions and rural communities around livelihoods, food and water security.
first-order administrative division
To enable the NTT province to strengthen climate resilience of its rural Communities to improve livelihood, food, and water security.
Annual Provincial and District government Work Plans and budgets approved by provincial and district parliaments that include specific reference to adaptation actions [refer to AMAT 1.1.1.1]

comment.narrative: Climate change is not integrated in provincial budgets and district budgets. The provincial Medium term development plan does not include any reference to climate change
budget allocation for adaptation actions in the Provincial Annual Work Plan and in the Annual Work Plans of at least three districts from 2014 onward.

The Project Objective has been partially achieved supported by following important building blocks that has been put in place to enable mainstreaming CCA in development planning and budgeting of NTT province and pilot districts by the end of the project: - Inclusion of climate change adaptation as one of priority issues in NTT Provincial Medium Term Development Plan 2013-2019 (Regional Regulation No.1/2014) has established a legal basis for planning and budget allocation for CCA in provincial, district to village level. - A village level Climate vulnerability and risk map for NTT province has been adopted by provincial and district development planning agency (Bappeda) as one of development planning references to inform locations and designing adaptation programme. The map has been distributed by provincial Bappeda to all districts in NTT province. - The project provided in depth technical assistance to related sectors in provincial and district governments such as agency of Agriculture, Food Security, Meteorology, Environment, Public Work, and Bappeda in planning CCA programme for 2015 and 2016 work plan. As a result, CCA-related activities such as water pond construction, rehabilitation of irrigation system, and improvement of rice variety have been included and budgeted in the 2015 work plan of the following sectoral government agencies in three district and provinces: Agency of Agriculture and Plantation, Food Security, the Forest Service, Department of Agriculture and Horticulture, Department of Public Works, Environment, the Regional Disaster Management, Office of Cooperative and Small and Medium Enterprises, Maritime Affairs and Fisheries. In the rest of the project lifecycle, these activities need to be monitored and their effectiveness validated in terms of their relevance to identified climate risks and vulnerability in targeted locations, to differentiate the CCA with Business-As-Usual development activities.

description.narrative: Institutional capacity developed to integrate climate resilience in sustainable development at provincial and district level
disaggregated by gender, number of trained people mandated to support climate resilient planning

comment.narrative: at least 100 trained people are mandated to support climate resilient planning

During this reporting period, a total of 229 individuals (189 male and 40 female) have been engaged various capacity building trainings, including the following:
- Training on CCA action plan and institutional work plan formulation targeting the following agencies from three district and Province: Bappeda, Public Work, Environment, Agriculture and Plantation, Food Security, Extension, Food Crop, Forestry, Fishery and Coastal, BPTP, UNDANA University, Cooperative and small scale business (34 male, 14 female);
- Training of Trainers on Climate Field School for district agencies and agricultural extension workers of the project pilot districts (17 male, 2 female). Provincial agencies and UNDANA were invited as the resource agencies.
- Technical training for village facilitators, extension workers in three pilot Districts (92 male, 16 female). This training focused on developing skill of field facilitators in advocating for integrating CCA activities in villages, sub district and districts development work plan.
- Training for local journalists on the climate change issues, its impacts on development and rural communities; and how to communicate it for public (46 male, 8 female). The trainer was an eminent environmental journalist from Kompas, a national newspaper. In addition to these trainings, the SPARC project initiated institutional support in the area of data management that contribute to the overall institutional capacity for integrating climate resilience in sub-national development planning. Through SPARC support, Bappeda and Stats Agency developed an online meta data system called “NTT Satu Data (NTT One Data)” which uses not just data from the Stats Dept, but also data collected through the SPARC-led vulnerability assessment and village socioeconomic assessment. It is expected to complement SIDIK (System Informasi Data Index Vulnerability) which is hosted at MoEF and contains a range of information including site-specific vulnerability and adaptation options. The information in NTT Satu Data and SIDIK is expected to contribute to an improved decision making and development planning at all levels.
-

description.narrative: number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimize exposure to climate variability (describe number and time) [refer to AMAT 2.2.1]

comment.narrative: no systematic institutional capacity development for adaptation is ongoing
At least 5 institutes have strengthened their systems, programmes and human resources to better address climate variability

Based on the identified climate risks and required CCA actions, the project focused on the following institutions those have authority and responsibility for implementing CCA actions in provincial and district level: Bappeda, BMKG, BPTP, Regional disaster management agency, Public Work, Environment agency, Agriculture, Plantation and Livestock agency, Food Security agency, Forestry agency and Fishery agency. In this reporting period, the project has provide technical assistance to the planner staff of above institutions to integrate CCA in the annual work plan for 2016 by using the climate risk and vulnerability map.

description.narrative: number and type of provincial and district level policies and programmes which have been adjusted / issued to address climate change resilience

comment.narrative: No integration of climate resilience in provincial and district policies and programmes
climate change resilience has been integrated in at least NTTâ€™s Medium Term Development Plan 2014-2018, and policies and programmes on agriculture and water

This indicator was achieved during the current reporting period. NTT’s Medium Term Development Plan (RPJMD) 2013-2018 is based on Regional Regulation No. 1 of 2014 and mentions specifically that CC mitigation and adaptation as one of strategic issues that the province has to consider. In particular, they are referenced under Mission #5: Accelerate the development of infrastructure based on spatial allocation and environmental considerations. Priority: Program to establish an information and communication system to improve the resilience of communities to climate change. Indicators: 1) Total forest that can be managed by communities as part of climate mitigation and adaptation; and 2) Plan for responses to disasters and climate change starting at the village level. In addition, Governor regulation No.29/2014 on Government Work Plan 2014 (RKPD 2014) has stated Priority Programme on CC mitigation and adaptation with targets: 23% of total forest area managed by communities and 22 districts have developed disaster and climate change action plan.

description.narrative: Livelihoods of vulnerable rural communities strengthened in a changing climate
climate risk reduction activities introduced at local level (list type and scope) [refer to AMAT 2.2.1.1]

comment.narrative: no climate risk reduction and awareness activities are introduced at local level;
At least 5 types of climate risk reduction measures have been introduced in the three target districts, of which at least three measures are specifically targeting women

Climate risk reduction measures have been implemented during this reporting period. In order to facilitate the community proposal formulation and grant disbursement processes, legal entities called Kemas ProKlim (“Community Group for Climate Programme”) were established, through support of the project team and NGO partners, in each of the target villages. One Kemas ProKlim consists of several primary community groups in a village and carry out various CCA activities. Kemas ProKlim has board at village level as well as administrative personnel that is responsible for managing grants and implementation of CCA activities. Standard operating Procedure for Kemas ProKlim operation has been developed including internal control framework for fund disbursement. In this reporting period, nine Kemas ProKlim (from nine villages – three villages per a pilot district) have developed CCA proposals and fund have been disbursed. In total, the nine Kemas Proklim consists of 64 community groups with 64 CCA activities related to food, water and livelihoods resilience covered in nine proposals. Additionally, 12 villages (four in each pilot district) are in process of establishing a Kemas ProKlim and in developing a CCA proposal facilitated by SPARC District coordinator, local government and NGO partner. The approved resilience building activities that are currently financed by the project include the following: - Three Kemas ProKlim in Manggarai District focus on crop diversification to gain household income (women activities), irrigation canal rehabilitation for rice fields production; improving crop resistant variety and planting system, pipeline installation for drinking water supply, land rehabilitation in landslides prone area, mattresses production (household activities for women group) and cattle fattening. - In Sumba Timur district, three Kemas ProKlim focus on improving rice field production (good practices, resistant variety), annual crop diversification, annual crop seedling for conservation of water catchment area and productive use, crop diversification, fish production, clean water supply. - In Sabu Raijua district, three Kemas Proklim implement CCA activities in improvement of clean water supply, crop diversification, dry land rice production, maize production and water catchment conservation.

description.narrative: % of households with a lower perception of vulnerability to climate risks due to new adaptation measures being introduced and applied, disaggregated by gender

comment.narrative: currently, the majority of households regard themselves as highly vulnerability to climate risks
at least 75% of the households that have implemented adaptation measures regard themselves less vulnerable to climate change related risks as a result

The implementation of CCA activities are targeting impact at household level, rather than village level. Based on the CCA proposals of Kemas Proklim, SPARC project team is currently developing monitoring tool to measure baseline situation of the participating households in CCA activities. Three short movies describing the baseline situation in 9 pioneering villages in 3 pilot districts have been developed for advocacy and monitoring: Voices of East Sumba
https://www.dropbox.com/l/9OWKurM4jbcbnEKjB5uJQo Voices of Manggarai
https://www.dropbox.com/l/ymFmq6eCpprFqYYpSpeKdt Voices of Sabu
https://www.dropbox.com/l/1A4nDgKVt0V5RjlpiHf9Hu These videos will be uploaded to UNDP Youtube

title.narrative: Technical Assistance to SDGs Implementation in Indonesia

description.narrative: Through the new PIP, UNDP will provide further technical assistance to the implementation of the SDGs in Indonesia (TA-SII) that will focus on three areas.
Policies and institutions for the governance and implementation of SDGs at national level are designed.
Policies and institutions for the governance and implementation of SDGs at provincial level are designed.
Management and Technical Assistance for Government and CSOs in Supporting the Implementation of Global Fund for AIDS, Tuberculosis, and Malaria in Indonesia as Contribution to SDG 3.
